name: p-bromotoluene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.
Reason: The benzene ring is the base structure, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. A p-substituted toluene generally has a higher melting point than benzene itself due to added steric hindrance and molecular weight, which contribute to its increase. A methyl group (toluene) adds approximately +20°C. The addition of a bromine atom, which is quite large and heavy, will further increase the melting point due to increased intermolecular London dispersion forces. The effect of a bromine atom generally contributes +30°C to the melting point.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. 
- The presence of a bromine atom increases the molecular weight and size, which generally increases the melting point due to stronger London dispersion forces. Bromine is a large, heavy atom, and its addition to the benzene ring is expected to increase the melting point by approximately +20 degrees Celsius. 
- The toluene part of the molecule adds a methyl group, which slightly increases the molecular weight and size, but it also introduces steric hindrance that can disrupt the crystal lattice, potentially lowering the melting point. The effect of the methyl group is estimated to be a decrease of about -5 degrees Celsius. 
- The overall prediction is the sum of the effects of the bromine and methyl groups on the benzene base.
